sentences.sentence: At the moment, not in the room itself but from somewhere very close, there came, first a rumbling( 隆隆声 ), then a creaking( 嘎吱作响声 ),
and then a roar( 咆哮声 ) of falling masonry( 砖石 ), and the floor shook.
“There is great peril( 危险 ) here,” said the Queen. “The whole palace is breaking up. If we are not out of it in a few minutes we shall be buried under the ruin.”
She spoke as calmly as if she had been merely mentioning the time of day. “Come,” she added, and held out a hand to each of the children.
Polly, who was disliking the Queen and feeling rather sulky( 闷闷不乐的 ), would not have let her hand be taken if she could have helped it.
But though the Queen spoke so calmly , her movements were as quick as thought.
Before Polly knew what was happening her left hand had been caught in a hand so much larger and stronger than her own that she could do nothing about it.
“This is a terrible woman,” thought Polly. “She’s strong enough to break my arm with one twist( 一扭 ).
And now that she’s got my left hand I can’t get at my yellow ring.
If I tried to stretch( 伸出 ) across and get my right hand into my left pocket I mightn’t be able to reach it, before she asked me what I was doing.
Whatever happens we mustn’t let her know about the rings.
I do hope Digory has the sense to keep his mouth shut. I wish I could get a word with him alone.”
The Queen led them out of the Hall of Images into a long corridor( 走廊 ) and then through a whole maze( 迷宫 ) of halls and stairs( 楼梯 ) and courtyards.
Again and again they heard parts of the great palace collapsing( 坍塌 ), sometimes quite close to them.
Once a huge arch( 拱门 ) came thundering down only a moment after they had passed through it.
The Queen was walking quickly—the children had to trot( 小跑 ) to keep up with her—but she showed no sign of fear.
Digory thought, “She’s wonderfully brave. And strong. She’s what I call a Queen!
I do hope she’s going to tell us the story of this place.”
She did tell them certain things as they went along:
“That is the door to the dungeons( 地牢 ),” she would say, or “That passage leads to the principal( 主要的 ) torture chambers( 拷问室 ),”
or “This was the old banqueting hall( 宴会厅 ) where my great-grandfather bade( 邀请 ) seven hundred nobles to a feast( 盛宴 ) and killed them all before they had drunk their fill.
They had had rebellious( 造反的 ) thoughts.”
They came at last into a hall larger and loftier( 更高的 ) than any they had yet seen.
From its size and from the great doors at the far end, Digory thought that now at last they must be coming to the main entrance.
In this he was quite right. The doors were dead black, either ebony( 乌木 ) or some black metal which is not found in our world.
They were fastened with great bars, most of them too high to reach and all too heavy to lift.
He wondered how they would get out.
The Queen let go of his hand and raised her arm.
She drew herself up to her full height and stood rigid( 笔直的 ).
Then she said something which they couldn’t understand (but it sounded horrid( 恐怖的 )) and made an action as if she were throwing something toward the doors.

And those high and heavy doors trembled( 颤动 ) for a second as if they were made of silk and then crumbled( 粉碎 ) away till there was nothing left of them but a heap( 一堆 ) of dust on the threshold( 门槛 ).
“Whew( 吁 )!” whistled Digory.
“Has your master magician, your uncle, power like mine?” asked the Queen, firmly seizing Digory’s hand again. “But I shall know later. In the meantime( 同时 ), remember what you have seen.
This is what happens to things, and to people, who stand in my way.”
Much more light than they had yet seen in that country was pouring in through the now empty doorway( 门口 ),
and when the Queen led them out through it they were not surprised to find themselves in the open air.
The wind that blew in their faces was cold, yet somehow stale( 污浊的 ).
They were looking from a high terrace( 高台 ) and there was a great landscape( 景色 ) spread out below them.
Low down and near the horizon( 地平线 ) hung a great, red sun, far bigger than our sun.
Digory felt at once that it was also older than ours: a sun near the end of its life, weary( 疲倦的 ) of looking down upon that world.
To the left of the sun, and higher up, there was a single star, big and bright.
Those were the only two things to be seen in the dark sky; they made a dismal( 阴郁的 ) group.
And on the earth, in every direction, as far as the eye could reach, there spread a vast city in which there was no living thing to be seen.
And all the temples, towers, palaces, pyramids( 金字塔 ), and bridges cast long, disastrous-looking shadows in the light of that withered( 衰弱的 ) sun.
Once a great river had flowed through the city, but the water had long since vanished( 消失 ),
and it was now only a wide ditch( 沟 ) of gray dust.
“Look well on that which no eyes will ever see again,” said the Queen.
“Such was Charn, that great city, the city of the King of Kings, the wonder of the world, perhaps of all worlds.
Does your uncle rule any city as great as this, boy?”
“No,” said Digory. He was going to explain that Uncle Andrew didn’t rule any cities, but the Queen went on:
“It is silent now.

But I have stood here when the whole air was full of the noises of Charn; the trampling( 踩踏声 ) of feet, the creaking( 嘎吱作响声 ) of wheels, the cracking( 噼啪声 ) of the whips( 皮鞭 ) and the groaning( 呻吟声 ) of slaves, the thunder of chariots( 战车 ), and the sacrificial( 用于祭祀的 ) drums beating in the temples.
I have stood here (but that was near the end) when the roar( 轰隆声 ) of battle went up from every street and the river of Charn ran red.”
She paused and added, “All in one moment one woman blotted it out( 毁掉 ) forever.”
“Who?” said Digory in a faint( 微弱的 ) voice; but he had already guessed the answer.
“I,” said the Queen. “I, Jadis, the last Queen, but the Queen of the World.”
The two children stood silent, shivering( 颤抖 ) in the cold wind.
“It was my sister’s fault,” said the Queen. “She drove me to it. May the curse( 诅咒 ) of all the Powers rest upon her forever!
At any moment I was ready to make peace—yes and to spare her life too, if only she would yield( 让位于... ) me the throne( 王位 ).
But she would not. Her pride has destroyed the whole world.
Even after the war had begun, there was a solemn( 郑重的 ) promise that neither side would use Magic.
But when she broke her promise, what could I do? Fool! As if she did not know that I had more Magic than she!
She even knew that I had the secret of the Deplorable Word( 灭绝咒 ).
Did she think—she was always a weakling( 懦弱者 )—that I would not use it?”
“What was it?” said Digory.
“That was the secret of secrets,” said the Queen Jadis. “It had long been known to the great kings of our race that there was a word which,
if spoken with the proper ceremonies, would destroy all living things except the one who spoke it.
But the ancient kings were weak and soft-hearted and bound themselves and all who should come after them with great oaths( 誓言 ) never even to seek after( 探索 ) the knowledge of that word.
But I learned it in a secret place and paid a terrible price to learn it.
I did not use it until she forced me to it. I fought to overcome her by every other means. I poured out the blood of my armies like water—”
“Beast!” muttered( 嘀咕 ) Polly.
“The last great battle,” said the Queen, “raged( 激烈地进行 ) for three days here in Charn itself.
For three days I looked down upon it from this very spot.
I did not use my power till the last of my soldiers had fallen, and the accursed( 可恶的 ) woman, my sister,
at the head of her rebels( 反叛者 ) was halfway up those great stairs( 楼梯 ) that lead up from the city to the terrace( 高地 ).
Then I waited till we were so close that we could see one another’s faces.
She flashed her horrible( 可怕的 ), wicked( 邪恶的 ) eyes upon me and said, ‘Victory.’ ‘Yes,’ said I, ‘Victory, but not yours.’
Then I spoke the Deplorable Word. A moment later I was the only living thing beneath the sun.”

article_info.previous: Polly和Digory小心翼翼地走进了这间满是蜡像的屋子。屋子中间石台上的金锤子和金钟引起了他们的注意。在好奇心的驱使下，Digory敲响了金钟，却没想到唤醒了沉睡多年的女王。

article_info.share_words: But I have stood here when the whole air was full of the noises of Charn; the trampling of feet, the creaking of wheels, the cracking of the whips and the groaning of slaves, the thunder of chariots, and the sacrificial drums beating in the temples.

question.cn: 根据描述，Polly是否喜欢女王？
question.en: According to the description, did Polly like the Queen?

analysis: 文中提到“Polly, who was disliking the Queen and feeling rather sulky, would not have let her hand be taken if she could have helped it.”从此处的描写可以看出，Polly并不喜欢女王，因此选B。

question.cn: 在一开始，Digory认为女王是怎样的人?
question.en: At the beginning, how did Digory feel about the Queen?

analysis: 文中提到“Digory thought, she’s wonderfully brave. And strong. She’s what I call a Queen!”由此可知，在一开始的时候，Digory认为女王十分得勇敢和强壮。因此选B。

question.cn: 为了逃出去，谁破坏了那扇高大笨重的门？
question.en: In order to get out, who broke the high and heavy doors?

analysis: 文中提到“The Queen let go of his hand and raised her arm… And those high and heavy doors trembled for a second as if they were made of silk and the crumbled away…”由此可知是女王举起手，对门施了咒语，就把门给摧毁了。因此选C。

question.en: What was the name of the Queen?

analysis: 文中提到 “I, said the Queen. I, Jadis, the last Queen, the Queen of the World.”因此可知女王的名字是Jadis. 因此选C。

question.cn: 根据对话的内容，女王口中“秘密中的秘密”是什么？
question.en: According to the conversation, what was the secret of secrets?

analysis: 文中提到“It had long been known to the great kings of our race that there was a word… which destroy all living things except one who spoke it…. I spoke the Deplorable Word. A moment later I was the only living thing beneath the sun.”由此可知秘密中的秘密应该是灭绝咒，因此选B。
